climbs.name: Winking Gargoyle
climbs.fa: Tony Calderone, Carrie Roberts & Vince Romney, 2006

content.description: A very mellow, short little route that is just over too quickly. Clip a bolt as you work up to the crack, place a cam or two in the crack, and then finish on easy slab climbing, clipping one more bolt on the way to the chains.
content.location: On the northeast corner of the Shark's Fin, look for the obvious large crack.

content.description: A fun short route with the crux right of the ground. Balance your way up on minimal feet and less than ideal hands just enough until you can move past the first bolt. Cruiser climbing above to the chains.
content.location: On the north side of the Shark's Fin formation, roughly 20 feet west from the Sorta Handy crack.

content.description: Climb up to large flake above a small tree.  Ascend the finger crack over a small bulge until you are established on the face.  Step to the right and clip the first bolt.  Transfer in a layback up large patina jugs.  Make a few hard moves and follow crimps to the top.
content.protection: 2 or 3 tips to finger pieces, 3 bolts.  Chains
content.location: North face of Sharks Fin.  20 feet left of Chumming on large ledge.  Easy slab approach through gate on south side off the road.

content.description: Start up easy slab climbing past the first two bolts. After clipping the third bolt, follow the holds slightly leftward until you can move past the slight overhang and onto the upper slab. Pass a couple more bolts straight up to the chain anchor.
content.location: On the north side of the Shark's Fin, this route is on right (west) side closest to the trail.

content.description:
A brilliant sport route on the overhanging side of the Shark's Fin. A burly move gets you off the ground - and shorter climbers might find this to be the crux. From here clip a few bolts on easier terrain before the crux at mid-level. Several different options exist for this super thin stretch of beautiful patina. Engaging 11+/12- climbing leads you to the chains from there.

Bolted by Mike Spaulding a few years back, I finished this project at the 2013 Idaho Mountain Festival. A great route.
content.location: On the steep, shady side of the Shark's Fin - facing the comp wall. It's right off the trail - hard to miss.
